## Prerequisites
* R and R-studio
* Download and decompress GEMINI database (large file, 83MB)
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B_bLL10GwDnsaXNNOW5EUDV0QjQ
* Download ad decompress additional tables
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B_bLL10GwDnsblgySWZjeHFFSUE
* Install packages: RSQLite, plyr
* Explore documentation: http://gemini.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
* Read the article: http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003153
* R code for the tutorial: https://github.com/naumenko-sa/tutorials/blob/master/gemini_tutorial.R

## 'Lazy bioinformatics' approach

```{r echo=F}
grid.roundrect(width=.25,height=.25,x=0.25,y=0.75)
grid.text("Raw sequencing \n data",x=0.25,y=0.75)

grid.move.to(0.4, .75)
grid.line.to(0.6, .75,arrow = arrow(angle=15))

grid.roundrect(width=.25,height=.25,x=0.75,y=0.75)
grid.text("Data processing \n with pipelines",x=0.75,y=0.75)

grid.move.to(0.75, .6)
grid.line.to(0.75, .4,arrow = arrow(angle=15))

grid.roundrect(width=.25,height=.25,x=0.75,y=0.25)
grid.text("Analysis in R",x=0.75,y=0.25)

grid.move.to(0.6, .25)
grid.line.to(0.4, .25,arrow = arrow(angle=15))

grid.roundrect(width=.25,height=.25,x=0.25,y=0.25)
grid.text("Reading & Writing",x=0.25,y=0.25)

grid.move.to(0.25, .4)
grid.line.to(0.25, .6,arrow = arrow(angle=15))
```

Only possible for simple analyses: Variants in whole exome sequencing, RNA-seq, Differential Expression

## How to organize this information in a neat format?

* Use dataframe in R or even a database
* GEMINI database
    + https://gemini.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
    + Paila U, Chapman BA, Kirchner R, Quinlan AR (2013)
GEMINI: Integrative Exploration of Genetic Variation and Genome Annotations.
PLoS Comput Biol 9(7): e1003153. doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003153 cited by 74
    + http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003153

## What is database?

- Database is a collection of related dataframes (tables);
- GEMINI uses SQLite database which does not require database server or database engine;
- database slang:
    + dataframe = table
    + column = field
    + select * from [table_name] where [condition];
- Web Interface to plot database schemas:
  http://ondras.zarovi.cz/sql/demo/?keyword=default

## How to load your variants into the GEMINI database?

- Ask your bioinformatics provider to send results in the GEMINI format;
- Ask CCM to convert vcf2gemini;
- Convert
    + [with gemini load (linux)](http://gemini.readthedocs.io/en/latest/content/preprocessing.html);
    + [vcf2db.py](https://github.com/quinlan-lab/vcf2db) 
- Use bcbio pipeline system â€“ it outputs GEMINI and vcf.

## Bcbio pipelines

- open source, community supported
- developed mainly by Harvard T.Chan Medical School Bioinformatics Core
- validated
- well documented
- easy to install and run
- Pipelines supported: (variant calling,cancer variants,structural variants, RNA-seq,smallRNA-seq,ChIP-seq")

- Resources
    + https://bcbio-nextgen.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
    + https://github.com/chapmanb/bcbio-nextgen
    + https://bcb.io

## Additional columns not present in GEMINI

- OMIM gene description (registration required)
- Orphanet status
- exac pLi score
- exac missense score
- imprinting status
- pseudoautosomal genes

## GTS field problem

* Gemini stores genotype information in the python-specific compressed format
* It is not easy to decompress in R
* Solution: 
    + gemini2txt first and then load to R 
    https://github.com/naumenko-sa/bioscripts/blob/master/gemini2txt.single_sample.mh.sh
    + use new loader https://github.com/quinlan-lab/vcf2db
